nodes.bodyText: Even though this is wired to be a no-op, shouldn't you still call start(), here?
yep
Even though this is wired to be a no-op, shouldn't you still call start(), here?
oops you are right! good catch
Can you add units to this? Is it minimum size in dp, px, etc? MINIMUM_IMAGE_SIZE_PX?

This is very broad. Can you throws SpecificSituationException, PredictionsException, under the condition of @throws SpecificSituationException Only when specific conditions A is met, and @throws PredictionsException this is the expected outcome of this test?
(Same for all.)
I would go further and drill down into the properties of the celebrity itself. What are reasonable/expected values for a blank image?
well... there isn't any property that I can look into since the result was empty haha. still, I think this is a pointless test at the moment, so i will just remove it
Possibly you could add a factory to our Assets utility, to read a reference directly as a Bitmap.  So that alongside Assets.readAsString, we have a new Assets.readAsBitmap.
good idea. Added

I really love the Stream APIs. But they are only available on Android as of API 24. If this were a unit test, that'd probably be okay, since we either don't involve Android in unit tests, or use Robolectric and assert a fairly high API level (28).
However, this will be problematic when we go to run the integration test suite on an API 16 device.
So, as much as I'd love to do streams, I think we need to avoid this, at least in this file, right now.
Rx has some similar functional concepts, and I have started using it in my test code, just so that I can regain some of these Java 8 functional behaviors, in an API-level-compatible fashion.
I'm not sure that there's any anyMatch() filter in Rx, but you could at least do:
assertTrue(Observable.fromIterable(restult.getCelebrities())
    .map(celeb -> celeb.getCelebrity().getName())
    .toList()
    .blockingGet()
    .contains("Jeff Bezos"));

Or, maybe similarly expressed with Hamcrest:
assertThat(
    Observable.fromIterable(restult.getCelebrities())
        .map(celeb -> celeb.getCelebrity().getName())
        .toList()
        .blockingGet(),
    containsInAnyOrder("Jeff Bezos")
);

Keep in mind that in order to achieve this you'd only need to add androidTestImplementation dependencies.rx, not implementation dependencies.rx.
I forget, do we have a version that doesn't require IdentifyOptions.defaults() as an arg? If so, you can probably wrap and keep this statement on the one line, L92.
No, I haven't made that overload in SynchronousPredictions yet. I will add it
haha lol
We have a CollectionUtils.isEmpty(...) in this project under core's utils, I believe. You could simplify these two checks into just assertFalse(CollectionUtils.isEmpty(labels)).
yep replacing with CollectionUtils#isNullOrEmpty(Collection)

Test consideration: Since this thing is just pure transformation of objects, all in memory with no dependencies, this would be extremely easy to get 100% unit test coverage over.

Design consideration: Elsewhere, you have for example a LandmarkTypeAdapter. That's an extensible pattern, one adapter per type. Takes in a service model, outputs an Amplify model.
If you have that pattern established, should you expand it to the factories in this class, too?
Among other things, I think it will clean up the naming. For example, instead of:
ImageResultTransformers.fromRekognitionPose(someServiceResult.getIt())

You'd have something like:
PoseTypeAdapter.fromRekognitionPose(someServiceResult.getIt())

Does the Rekognition SDK not enum this literals, itself?
I know we've discussed in this in prior PRs. And I did buy your argument - like, we don't need this to be an enum-to-enum map.
I guess I'm just surprised that the code-gen'd service model doesn't give you an enum of the landmarks, itself.

nodes.bodyText:
Since this is public-access, and since it has a constructor with a bunch of args, I would add class documentation to this that says something like "This is an internal class. Don't use it."
Ah man actually -- if we had really had our ducks in a row, classes like this would have .internal. in their Java package names. Like com.amplifyframework.predictions.aws.internal.AWSIdentifyOperation or something? Anyway, restructuring our plugins is obviously outside the scope of this current PR.
I agree. There is a BUNCH of items that should have been packaged as internal. Maybe package rearrangement is something we can look into in our final week before release... across the entire project
Note to self: come back to this...
@jamesonwilliams reminder to come back to this ;)

nodes.bodyText: Hmm, that's a good point. There are a lot of models at the moment, and I will make another PR to address it to every model in the module
getRowCount() getRowSize() ? When I see getRows(), I expect it to return a collection of some kind.
Good point. I'll do that
Renamed to RowSize and ColumnSize
Same deal -- also particularly since getCells() returns a collection. The names would lead you to think all three have the same return type, currently.
fixed

What's the use case for doing this after object construction?
Also, if a selection isn't selected -- wouldn't one just not create the selection to begin with?
In other words, if I have like aSet<Selection>, I would expect that to contain only active selections.
Maybe there is a use-case here? In which case, should this be named like isActive()? With a bit of Javadoc to guide the user on when/why they might care / expect this to be true/false?
Good point! Upon looking at the iOS model, it seems the boolean is final, so it shouldn't have been settable after construction. Will fix

Some of these are intuitive. Not to say that they couldn't all benefit from technical specificity.
However, these ones, to me, are not intuitive.

NOSE_CREST
MEDIAN_LINE
FACE_CONTOUR

I think my nose crest is the portion of my face's median line that runs up-down in middle of my nose. But, maybe not?
Face contour - like, is my face fat?

nodes.bodyText: When/why would the case differ? Can't we just tighten up the usage is always the same, and then do a literal equals(...) check? This is a slippery slope

this is comparison implementation. Sure I could have just used compareTo instead of compareToIgnoreCase, but I figured this would be convenient. Comparing two features of different type is not an appropriate use-case anyways

In this builder, you permit a number of @Nullable options. What is their purpose? If a user sets a field to null, does it clear it? And mean "I don't know"? Or, what are the implications of leaving these things unspecified? When can an EntityDetails have different collections of these various properties?

It means that some of the properties that our implementation chose to detect are not required for other plugins to detect. So, a null would mean "I do not detect this value in my implementation of identify".
Wait I forget, why not just return FeatureType form this interface? The String discards your constraint set.
